newsArray.title: World Cup team left with just 14 outfield players due to FIFA rule after four are banished
newsArray.description: A World Cup team has been left with just 14 outfield players after four of them were sent home in disgrace with FIFA rulings barring any replacements
newsArray.content: The U17 has been hit by a serious scandal that has seen four players banished from the national camp. Poland‚Äôs preparations for the tournament have been marred after four of their players were banished from the team‚Äôs training camp after they were removed due to unsportsmanlike behaviour and violation of the regulations ‚Äì having been caught with alcohol. And the four departing players - Oskar Tomczyk, Filip Rozga, Jan Labedzki, and Filip Wolski - cannot be replaced due to FIFA ruling ‚Äì meaning Poland now only have 14 outfield players to select from due to the regulations regarding replacements on the submitted player list. FIFA addressed the situation regarding the axed players, saying: ‚ÄúAs per Article 27.3 of the tournament regulations, a player listed on the final list may be replaced by a player from the provisional list only in the event of serious injury or illness up until 24 hours before the kick-off of their team‚Äôs first match.‚Äù Poland U17 coach Marcin Wlodarski admitted he felt the team's scandal was a ‚Äòpersonal failure‚Äô of his. He said: "The players broke the rules and there was no other option but for them to leave the team. I see these boys as family, we spend a lot of time together. So I treat this as a personal failure of mine. "We cannot let such acts slide. I believe these boys will reflect on this, understand that their actions have consequences and re-join the team one day, just not anytime soon. I've spoken with the parents and everyone is disappointed. "Everyone worked hard to get here, but we need to condemn this, because these things cannot happen, especially not on the national team. For each of these boys, I would have cut my hand off for them and now I wouldn't have a hand." Poland played their opening tournament game on Saturday, falling to a 1-0 defeat against Japan, where they were able to name just six substitutes. They find themselves in one of the toughest groups in the tournament, alongside Senegal and Argentina ‚Äì where all eyes will be on 15-year-old Senegal sensation .

newsArray.title: Premier League referees' chiefs advertise new VAR job after Mikel Arteta "disgrace" rant
creator: mirrornews@mirror.co.uk (Nathan Ridley)
newsArray.description: The future of VAR in the Premier League continues to make headlines, with the PGMOL still reeling from Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta's furious blast last weekend
newsArray.content: The PGMOL are looking to recruit new "specialist" VAR officials amid the increasing criticism of its use in the Premier League . VAR once again stole the headlines last weekend after Arsenal suffered a controversial 1-0 defeat away to Newcastle , with Anthony Gordon's winning goal being subject to a lengthy check to decide on three incidents within the build-up. That prompted Arsenal boss Mikel Arteta to furiously label the officiating a "disgrace," and now the PGMOL - the body in charge of the Premier League's referees - are ramping up their efforts to improve VAR. The Sun report that an advert is currently circulating among 75 elite referees in both the men's and women's game for staff who'd work specifically to help video assistant referees. The advert is asking for officials who can "provide clear communication under pressure" and are "capable of self-reflection on how they have performed." Erik ten Hag could get unlikely VAR wish after controversial Man Utd incidents Graeme Souness speaks out after Mikel Arteta is slammed following "embarrassing" VAR rant It's also stated that they'd need to "identify when VAR needs to intervene," and have the "ability to focus and have great communication skills." Last season, retired on-field referee Mike Dean took up a role dedicated to VAR, following in former colleague Lee Mason's footsteps. However, both Dean and Mason left their respective roles earlier this year amid the intense scrutiny on VAR. This week, in the wake of Arteta's infamous post-match rant, the Premier League's Key Match Incidents panel ruled that Newcastle's goal was indeed correctly awarded. Have your say! Should the Premier League scrap VAR? Let us know your stance in the comments section . Mikel Arteta labelled the officiating during Arsenal's 1-0 defeat to Newcastle a "disgrace" ( Image: Stu Forster/Getty Images) When quizzed on the panel's verdict, which also found that Arsenal midfielder Kai Havertz should've been shown a red card for a reckless challenge in the first half, Arteta attempted to move away from the topic. "I think we had a lot of reactions after that match," the Gunners boss said on Friday. "It's time to move forward, to focus on Burnley and talk about tomorrow's game." Nevertheless, Arteta was pressed to discuss VAR and comment on reports that it could take 10 years to iron out its imperfections. "I will probably be bald in 10 years," he joked. "Life will be very different, maybe we will have other new rules in football, so I don't know. Let's try to do everything that we can, individually and collectively to improve the game in every aspect and that's it." Join our new WhatsApp community! newsArray.description: Manchester United are reportedly planning to offload three of their senior attackers when the January transfer window opens.
newsArray.content: Manchester United are reportedly planning to offload three of their senior attackers when the January transfer window opens. The United has been nothing short of disappointing, with Marcus Rashford being the only wide or forward player to score a goal in the Premier League. The Sun have reported that the club are now looking to offload Anthony Martial, Jadon Sancho and Antony as they aim to cut ties on their losses. Sancho has not featured since the loss to Tottenham Hotspur earlier in the season after falling out with manager Erik ten Hag, with the player not expected to feature for the club again. Martial has only scored one goal in all competitions this season but has played second fiddle to Rasmus Hojlund, while ¬£85million signing Antony has failed to impress since joining the club last season. The report adds the moves comes as Sir Jim Ratcliffe is set to take over football matters at the club when he completes a deal to buy 25 per cent of the Red Devils. Antony was linked with a return to Brazil earlier this week, but Flamengo vice president has already ruled out a swap move involving Gabriel Barbosa. newsArray.title: 'I tackled everyone I could during Arsenal training ‚Äì even Arsene Wenger'
newsArray.description: Kolo Toure told his side of the story about his infamous Arsenal trial which saw him 'trying to tackle everything' ‚Äì including Arsene Wenger
newsArray.content: Kolo Toure admitted he was "trying to tackle everything" during his infamous trial that saw him take out . Toure‚Äôs first days at Arsenal are well known. And for anyone who watched his career unfold, the story about his trial as a 21-year-old while he was still at ASEC Mimosas in his homeland will come as little surprise. A recording of former Arsenal hero Ray Parlour‚Äôs story was played about how Toure smashed into Thierry Henry and Dennis Bergkamp ‚Äì with Wenger shrieking at him not to go in heavy on the Gunners‚Äô star players. Parlour later told how after making a good interception, Toure followed the ball out before smashing into Wenger and leaving the man he was trying to impress in pain on the deck. Toure listened to the recording with a huge smile on his face before telling his side of the story to former Arsenal team-mate Martin Keown on talkSPORT. He said: ‚ÄúLike Martin said, I was so enthusiastic. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe I was training with these guys, coming there and with players that were my idols. When the game started, I wanted to show what I was capable of doing because for me it was a big chance and I didn‚Äôt want to miss that at all. I was trying to tackle everything I could, including the manager.‚Äù Keown added how Wenger was impressed by Toure‚Äôs mentality, immediately wanting to offer the Ivorian a contract, he said: ‚ÄúDo you remember what the manager said? He was getting to his feet and he said ‚Äòwe sign him, we sign him, please do it‚Äô.‚Äù That quip saw both of the former Invincibles burst into laughter. Toure went on to play 326 games in all competitions for Arsenal across seven years in North London ‚Äì lifting the and FA Cup twice at Arsenal. He later joined in 2009, going on to win a further Premier League title and FA Cup. After leaving the Etihad, Toure played for three years at Liverpool before moving north of the border and playing under Brendan Rodgers at Celtic for a short spell before becoming part of his coaching staff at Parkhead and . Toure most recently took charge of last season but was sacked after going winless in his nine games in charge.

newsArray.content: C lubs with a coherent recruitment process do not really do regrets. It is why Manchester City are unlikely to be caught fretting about selling Cole Palmer to Chelsea in the summer. Outsiders may view it as a risk, particularly as Palmer is in excellent form before facing his boyhood club on Sunday afternoon, but City are hardly short of attacking talent and conduct their transfer business in a way that means they do not have to second-guess themselves about letting players go. Still Chelsea are entitled to argue that they got a bargain when they signed Palmer for ¬£40m plus ¬£2.5m in add-ons. Sometimes everyone leaves a negotiation feeling triumphant. In this case City bolstered their financial fair play position by selling a homegrown player who was on the fringes of the first team, Chelsea paid relatively little for a top young talent and Palmer joined a club who, for all their instability, were ready to offer him regular football. Nobody has to feel bitter. Palmer hoped this would be his breakthrough season at City, especially after Riyad Mahrez moved to Saudi Arabia, and there were positive signs at the start of the campaign. The 21-year-old scored a gorgeous goal against Arsenal in the Community Shield and headed in City‚Äôs equaliser against Sevilla in the European Super Cup . Was Palmer about to follow in the footsteps of another of City‚Äôs academy stars, Phil Foden, and force his way into Pep Guardiola‚Äôs plans? Foden is established with City and England, but Guardiola clearly liked Palmer and gave him opportunities last season. Cole Palmer occupies the Sevilla defence during Manchester City‚Äôs Super Cup victory in August. Photograph: Raddad Jebarah/NurPhoto/Getty Images When it came to the crunch, though, City could not quite justify keeping Palmer around. European champions tend to be ruthless. Guardiola, who also had Kevin De Bruyne, Jack Grealish, Juli√°n √Ålvarez, Bernardo Silva and Foden, looked elsewhere. The writing was on the wall for Palmer when City signed Matheus Nunes and J√©r√©my Doku. It made no sense for Palmer to stay and fight for his place. He played a key role in England winning the European Under-21 Championship in July and could not afford to be sidelined. Other avenues were waiting to be explored. City had rejected Brighton‚Äôs ¬£35m bid for Palmer and there was interest from Burnley and West Ham. Drumming up a deal for the attacker was not going to be a problem. Even so it would be wrong to say Palmer was Chelsea‚Äôs first choice given they came within a whisker of signing Michael Olise from Crystal Palace. It is true that Joe Shields, the co-director of recruitment and talent, knew Palmer from his time at City‚Äôs academy. Shields could vouch for Palmer‚Äôs ability and Chelsea spent much of the summer quietly monitoring the situation. skip past newsletter promotion Sign up to Football Daily Free daily newsletter Kick off your evenings with the Guardian's take on the world of football Privacy Notice: Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. He is a regular starter at his new club. Photograph: Javier Garc√≠a/Shutterstock Yet the move itself was opportunistic. Chelsea were short in attack after losing Christopher Nkunku and Carney Chukwuemeka to injury. Mauricio Pochettino called for reinforcements. Chelsea, notoriously blunt in the final third, needed help. However, eyebrows were raised when Palmer was added to a squad already packed with youth; it seemed odd that Chelsea would sign a right-sided attacker when they had Raheem Sterling, Noni Madueke and Mykhailo Mudryk. There were fears that Palmer would be swallowed up. He is from Wythenshawe, south Manchester, and had only known life at City. He is alone in London, away from his family, and has delivered a few self-deprecating lines about missing his mum‚Äôs cooking and learning how to use a washing machine. Do not mistake that for a lack of self-belief, though. Palmer has embraced the challenge and quickly become one of the symbols of Chelsea‚Äôs youth-led revolution. Having been eased in by Pochettino, Palmer has not looked back since coming into the starting XI. He announced himself with an assist on his debut in Brighton and excelled on his first league start, making Armando Broja‚Äôs goal in Chelsea‚Äôs win over Fulham . Pochettino has seen a player seizing responsibility. Palmer has assumed penalty duties, scoring three times from the spot, and captained England Under-21s last month. Chelsea are mid-table and have issues in attack but Palmer is not one of them. Capable of playing on the right, and even impressing as a false 9 against Arsenal last month, he has infused Pochettino‚Äôs side with ideas and invention. This is not a luxury player. When he was 16 Palmer was behind others in his age group at City. He was smaller so he focused on developing his footwork. He figured out how to escape tight situations. The growth spurt followed. At 6ft, Palmer is no pushover. He can handle the physical side, even if he still looks slender, and is not easy to dispossess. Along with the clever passing, there is an elegance to Palmer‚Äôs movement and the way he unbalances defenders. There was an instructive moment at the start of Chelsea‚Äôs wild 4-1 win over Tottenham on Monday. The visitors were under pressure after going 1-0 down and were being pressed by Spurs. But when Palmer picked up possession in his own half and found himself being pushed backwards, he stayed calm, trusted in his technique and bamboozled Destiny Udogie with a sublime Cruyff turn. No wonder Gareth Southgate is keeping an eye on Palmer, who could be drafted into the England squad after James Maddison‚Äôs withdrawal through injury. No wonder Chelsea are no longer having to answer questions about selling Mason Mount and Kai Havertz. Palmer has brightened the picture and although City will back their long-term judgment they will not underestimate their former player on Sunday afternoon.

newsArray.title: World Cup team left with just 14 outfield players due to FIFA rule after four are banished
newsArray.description: A World Cup team has been left with just 14 outfield players after four of them were sent home in disgrace with FIFA rulings barring any replacements
newsArray.content: The U17 has been hit by a serious scandal that has seen four players banished from the national camp. Poland‚Äôs preparations for the tournament have been marred after four of their players were banished from the team‚Äôs training camp after they were removed due to unsportsmanlike behaviour and violation of the regulations ‚Äì having been caught with alcohol. And the four departing players - Oskar Tomczyk, Filip Rozga, Jan Labedzki, and Filip Wolski - cannot be replaced due to FIFA ruling ‚Äì meaning Poland now only have 14 outfield players to select from due to the regulations regarding replacements on the submitted player list. FIFA addressed the situation regarding the axed players, saying: ‚ÄúAs per Article 27.3 of the tournament regulations, a player listed on the final list may be replaced by a player from the provisional list only in the event of serious injury or illness up until 24 hours before the kick-off of their team‚Äôs first match.‚Äù Poland U17 coach Marcin Wlodarski admitted he felt the team's scandal was a ‚Äòpersonal failure‚Äô of his. He said: "The players broke the rules and there was no other option but for them to leave the team. I see these boys as family, we spend a lot of time together. So I treat this as a personal failure of mine. "We cannot let such acts slide. I believe these boys will reflect on this, understand that their actions have consequences and re-join the team one day, just not anytime soon. I've spoken with the parents and everyone is disappointed. "Everyone worked hard to get here, but we need to condemn this, because these things cannot happen, especially not on the national team. For each of these boys, I would have cut my hand off for them and now I wouldn't have a hand." Poland played their opening tournament game on Saturday, falling to a 1-0 defeat against Japan, where they were able to name just six substitutes. They find themselves in one of the toughest groups in the tournament, alongside Senegal and Argentina ‚Äì where all eyes will be on 15-year-old Senegal sensation .

creator: mirrornews@mirror.co.uk (Nathan Ridley)
newsArray.description: The future of VAR in the Premier League continues to make headlines, with the PGMOL still reeling from Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta's furious blast last weekend
newsArray.content: The PGMOL are looking to recruit new "specialist" VAR officials amid the increasing criticism of its use in the Premier League . VAR once again stole the headlines last weekend after Arsenal suffered a controversial 1-0 defeat away to Newcastle , with Anthony Gordon's winning goal being subject to a lengthy check to decide on three incidents within the build-up. That prompted Arsenal boss Mikel Arteta to furiously label the officiating a "disgrace," and now the PGMOL - the body in charge of the Premier League's referees - are ramping up their efforts to improve VAR. The Sun report that an advert is currently circulating among 75 elite referees in both the men's and women's game for staff who'd work specifically to help video assistant referees. The advert is asking for officials who can "provide clear communication under pressure" and are "capable of self-reflection on how they have performed." Erik ten Hag could get unlikely VAR wish after controversial Man Utd incidents Graeme Souness speaks out after Mikel Arteta is slammed following "embarrassing" VAR rant It's also stated that they'd need to "identify when VAR needs to intervene," and have the "ability to focus and have great communication skills." Last season, retired on-field referee Mike Dean took up a role dedicated to VAR, following in former colleague Lee Mason's footsteps. However, both Dean and Mason left their respective roles earlier this year amid the intense scrutiny on VAR. This week, in the wake of Arteta's infamous post-match rant, the Premier League's Key Match Incidents panel ruled that Newcastle's goal was indeed correctly awarded. Have your say! Should the Premier League scrap VAR? Let us know your stance in the comments section . Mikel Arteta labelled the officiating during Arsenal's 1-0 defeat to Newcastle a "disgrace" ( Image: Stu Forster/Getty Images) When quizzed on the panel's verdict, which also found that Arsenal midfielder Kai Havertz should've been shown a red card for a reckless challenge in the first half, Arteta attempted to move away from the topic. "I think we had a lot of reactions after that match," the Gunners boss said on Friday. "It's time to move forward, to focus on Burnley and talk about tomorrow's game." Nevertheless, Arteta was pressed to discuss VAR and comment on reports that it could take 10 years to iron out its imperfections. "I will probably be bald in 10 years," he joked. "Life will be very different, maybe we will have other new rules in football, so I don't know. Let's try to do everything that we can, individually and collectively to improve the game in every aspect and that's it." Join our new WhatsApp community! newsArray.description: Manchester United are reportedly planning to offload three of their senior attackers when the January transfer window opens.
newsArray.content: Manchester United are reportedly planning to offload three of their senior attackers when the January transfer window opens. The United has been nothing short of disappointing, with Marcus Rashford being the only wide or forward player to score a goal in the Premier League. The Sun have reported that the club are now looking to offload Anthony Martial, Jadon Sancho and Antony as they aim to cut ties on their losses. Sancho has not featured since the loss to Tottenham Hotspur earlier in the season after falling out with manager Erik ten Hag, with the player not expected to feature for the club again. Martial has only scored one goal in all competitions this season but has played second fiddle to Rasmus Hojlund, while ¬£85million signing Antony has failed to impress since joining the club last season. The report adds the moves comes as Sir Jim Ratcliffe is set to take over football matters at the club when he completes a deal to buy 25 per cent of the Red Devils. Antony was linked with a return to Brazil earlier this week, but Flamengo vice president has already ruled out a swap move involving Gabriel Barbosa. Sancho, meanwhile, has been linked with a return to Bundesliga outfit Borussia Dortmund while a couple Premier League are also reportedly said to be keen. You must be to read and post comments

newsArray.description: Kolo Toure told his side of the story about his infamous Arsenal trial which saw him 'trying to tackle everything' ‚Äì including Arsene Wenger
newsArray.content: Kolo Toure admitted he was "trying to tackle everything" during his infamous trial that saw him take out . Toure‚Äôs first days at Arsenal are well known. And for anyone who watched his career unfold, the story about his trial as a 21-year-old while he was still at ASEC Mimosas in his homeland will come as little surprise. A recording of former Arsenal hero Ray Parlour‚Äôs story was played about how Toure smashed into Thierry Henry and Dennis Bergkamp ‚Äì with Wenger shrieking at him not to go in heavy on the Gunners‚Äô star players. Parlour later told how after making a good interception, Toure followed the ball out before smashing into Wenger and leaving the man he was trying to impress in pain on the deck. Toure listened to the recording with a huge smile on his face before telling his side of the story to former Arsenal team-mate Martin Keown on talkSPORT. He said: ‚ÄúLike Martin said, I was so enthusiastic. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe I was training with these guys, coming there and with players that were my idols. When the game started, I wanted to show what I was capable of doing because for me it was a big chance and I didn‚Äôt want to miss that at all. I was trying to tackle everything I could, including the manager.‚Äù Keown added how Wenger was impressed by Toure‚Äôs mentality, immediately wanting to offer the Ivorian a contract, he said: ‚ÄúDo you remember what the manager said? He was getting to his feet and he said ‚Äòwe sign him, we sign him, please do it‚Äô.‚Äù That quip saw both of the former Invincibles burst into laughter. Toure went on to play 326 games in all competitions for Arsenal across seven years in North London ‚Äì lifting the and FA Cup twice at Arsenal. He later joined in 2009, going on to win a further Premier League title and FA Cup. After leaving the Etihad, Toure played for three years at Liverpool before moving north of the border and playing under Brendan Rodgers at Celtic for a short spell before becoming part of his coaching staff at Parkhead and . Toure most recently took charge of last season but was sacked after going winless in his nine games in charge.

newsArray.content: C lubs with a coherent recruitment process do not really do regrets. It is why Manchester City are unlikely to be caught fretting about selling Cole Palmer to Chelsea in the summer. Outsiders may view it as a risk, particularly as Palmer is in excellent form before facing his boyhood club on Sunday afternoon, but City are hardly short of attacking talent and conduct their transfer business in a way that means they do not have to second-guess themselves about letting players go. Still Chelsea are entitled to argue that they got a bargain when they signed Palmer for ¬£40m plus ¬£2.5m in add-ons. Sometimes everyone leaves a negotiation feeling triumphant. In this case City bolstered their financial fair play position by selling a homegrown player who was on the fringes of the first team, Chelsea paid relatively little for a top young talent and Palmer joined a club who, for all their instability, were ready to offer him regular football. Nobody has to feel bitter. Palmer hoped this would be his breakthrough season at City, especially after Riyad Mahrez moved to Saudi Arabia, and there were positive signs at the start of the campaign. The 21-year-old scored a gorgeous goal against Arsenal in the Community Shield and headed in City‚Äôs equaliser against Sevilla in the European Super Cup . Was Palmer about to follow in the footsteps of another of City‚Äôs academy stars, Phil Foden, and force his way into Pep Guardiola‚Äôs plans? Foden is established with City and England, but Guardiola clearly liked Palmer and gave him opportunities last season. Cole Palmer occupies the Sevilla defence during Manchester City‚Äôs Super Cup victory in August. Photograph: Raddad Jebarah/NurPhoto/Getty Images When it came to the crunch, though, City could not quite justify keeping Palmer around. European champions tend to be ruthless. Guardiola, who also had Kevin De Bruyne, Jack Grealish, Juli√°n √Ålvarez, Bernardo Silva and Foden, looked elsewhere. The writing was on the wall for Palmer when City signed Matheus Nunes and J√©r√©my Doku. It made no sense for Palmer to stay and fight for his place. He played a key role in England winning the European Under-21 Championship in July and could not afford to be sidelined. Other avenues were waiting to be explored. City had rejected Brighton‚Äôs ¬£35m bid for Palmer and there was interest from Burnley and West Ham. Drumming up a deal for the attacker was not going to be a problem. Even so it would be wrong to say Palmer was Chelsea‚Äôs first choice given they came within a whisker of signing Michael Olise from Crystal Palace. It is true that Joe Shields, the co-director of recruitment and talent, knew Palmer from his time at City‚Äôs academy. Shields could vouch for Palmer‚Äôs ability and Chelsea spent much of the summer quietly monitoring the situation. skip past newsletter promotion Sign up to Football Daily Free daily newsletter Kick off your evenings with the Guardian's take on the world of football Privacy Notice: Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see our Privacy Policy . We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. after newsletter promotion Mauricio Pochettino watches Cole Palmer in action for Chelsea. He is a regular starter at his new club. Photograph: Javier Garc√≠a/Shutterstock Yet the move itself was opportunistic. Chelsea were short in attack after losing Christopher Nkunku and Carney Chukwuemeka to injury. Mauricio Pochettino called for reinforcements. Chelsea, notoriously blunt in the final third, needed help. However, eyebrows were raised when Palmer was added to a squad already packed with youth; it seemed odd that Chelsea would sign a right-sided attacker when they had Raheem Sterling, Noni Madueke and Mykhailo Mudryk. There were fears that Palmer would be swallowed up. He is from Wythenshawe, south Manchester, and had only known life at City. He is alone in London, away from his family, and has delivered a few self-deprecating lines about missing his mum‚Äôs cooking and learning how to use a washing machine. Do not mistake that for a lack of self-belief, though. Palmer has embraced the challenge and quickly become one of the symbols of Chelsea‚Äôs youth-led revolution. Having been eased in by Pochettino, Palmer has not looked back since coming into the starting XI. He announced himself with an assist on his debut in Brighton and excelled on his first league start, making Armando Broja‚Äôs goal in Chelsea‚Äôs win over Fulham . Pochettino has seen a player seizing responsibility. Palmer has assumed penalty duties, scoring three times from the spot, and captained England Under-21s last month. Chelsea are mid-table and have issues in attack but Palmer is not one of them. Capable of playing on the right, and even impressing as a false 9 against Arsenal last month, he has infused Pochettino‚Äôs side with ideas and invention. This is not a luxury player. When he was 16 Palmer was behind others in his age group at City. He was smaller so he focused on developing his footwork. He figured out how to escape tight situations. The growth spurt followed. At 6ft, Palmer is no pushover. He can handle the physical side, even if he still looks slender, and is not easy to dispossess. Along with the clever passing, there is an elegance to Palmer‚Äôs movement and the way he unbalances defenders. There was an instructive moment at the start of Chelsea‚Äôs wild 4-1 win over Tottenham on Monday. The visitors were under pressure after going 1-0 down and were being pressed by Spurs. But when Palmer picked up possession in his own half and found himself being pushed backwards, he stayed calm, trusted in his technique and bamboozled Destiny Udogie with a sublime Cruyff turn. No wonder Gareth Southgate is keeping an eye on Palmer, who could be drafted into the England squad after James Maddison‚Äôs withdrawal through injury. No wonder Chelsea are no longer having to answer questions about selling Mason Mount and Kai Havertz. Palmer has brightened the picture and although City will back their long-term judgment they will not underestimate their former player on Sunday afternoon.

newsArray.title: World Cup team left with just 14 outfield players due to FIFA rule after four are banished
newsArray.description: A World Cup team has been left with just 14 outfield players after four of them were sent home in disgrace with FIFA rulings barring any replacements
newsArray.content: The U17 has been hit by a serious scandal that has seen four players banished from the national camp. Poland‚Äôs preparations for the tournament have been marred after four of their players were banished from the team‚Äôs training camp after they were removed due to unsportsmanlike behaviour and violation of the regulations ‚Äì having been caught with alcohol. And the four departing players - Oskar Tomczyk, Filip Rozga, Jan Labedzki, and Filip Wolski - cannot be replaced due to FIFA ruling ‚Äì meaning Poland now only have 14 outfield players to select from due to the regulations regarding replacements on the submitted player list. FIFA addressed the situation regarding the axed players, saying: ‚ÄúAs per Article 27.3 of the tournament regulations, a player listed on the final list may be replaced by a player from the provisional list only in the event of serious injury or illness up until 24 hours before the kick-off of their team‚Äôs first match.‚Äù Poland U17 coach Marcin Wlodarski admitted he felt the team's scandal was a ‚Äòpersonal failure‚Äô of his. He said: "The players broke the rules and there was no other option but for them to leave the team. I see these boys as family, we spend a lot of time together. So I treat this as a personal failure of mine. "We cannot let such acts slide. I believe these boys will reflect on this, understand that their actions have consequences and re-join the team one day, just not anytime soon. I've spoken with the parents and everyone is disappointed. "Everyone worked hard to get here, but we need to condemn this, because these things cannot happen, especially not on the national team. For each of these boys, I would have cut my hand off for them and now I wouldn't have a hand." Poland played their opening tournament game on Saturday, falling to a 1-0 defeat against Japan, where they were able to name just six substitutes. They find themselves in one of the toughest groups in the tournament, alongside Senegal and Argentina ‚Äì where all eyes will be on 15-year-old Senegal sensation .

creator: mirrornews@mirror.co.uk (Nathan Ridley)
newsArray.description: The future of VAR in the Premier League continues to make headlines, with the PGMOL still reeling from Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta's furious blast last weekend
newsArray.content: The PGMOL are looking to recruit new "specialist" VAR officials amid the increasing criticism of its use in the Premier League . VAR once again stole the headlines last weekend after Arsenal suffered a controversial 1-0 defeat away to Newcastle , with Anthony Gordon's winning goal being subject to a lengthy check to decide on three incidents within the build-up. That prompted Arsenal boss Mikel Arteta to furiously label the officiating a "disgrace," and now the PGMOL - the body in charge of the Premier League's referees - are ramping up their efforts to improve VAR. The Sun report that an advert is currently circulating among 75 elite referees in both the men's and women's game for staff who'd work specifically to help video assistant referees. The advert is asking for officials who can "provide clear communication under pressure" and are "capable of self-reflection on how they have performed." Erik ten Hag could get unlikely VAR wish after controversial Man Utd incidents Graeme Souness speaks out after Mikel Arteta is slammed following "embarrassing" VAR rant It's also stated that they'd need to "identify when VAR needs to intervene," and have the "ability to focus and have great communication skills." Last season, retired on-field referee Mike Dean took up a role dedicated to VAR, following in former colleague Lee Mason's footsteps. However, both Dean and Mason left their respective roles earlier this year amid the intense scrutiny on VAR. This week, in the wake of Arteta's infamous post-match rant, the Premier League's Key Match Incidents panel ruled that Newcastle's goal was indeed correctly awarded. Have your say! Should the Premier League scrap VAR? Let us know your stance in the comments section . Mikel Arteta labelled the officiating during Arsenal's 1-0 defeat to Newcastle a "disgrace" ( Image: Stu Forster/Getty Images) When quizzed on the panel's verdict, which also found that Arsenal midfielder Kai Havertz should've been shown a red card for a reckless challenge in the first half, Arteta attempted to move away from the topic. "I think we had a lot of reactions after that match," the Gunners boss said on Friday. "It's time to move forward, to focus on Burnley and talk about tomorrow's game." Nevertheless, Arteta was pressed to discuss VAR and comment on reports that it could take 10 years to iron out its imperfections. "I will probably be bald in 10 years," he joked. "Life will be very different, maybe we will have other new rules in football, so I don't know. newsArray.content: Kolo Toure admitted he was "trying to tackle everything" during his infamous trial that saw him take out . Toure‚Äôs first days at Arsenal are well known. And for anyone who watched his career unfold, the story about his trial as a 21-year-old while he was still at ASEC Mimosas in his homeland will come as little surprise. A recording of former Arsenal hero Ray Parlour‚Äôs story was played about how Toure smashed into Thierry Henry and Dennis Bergkamp ‚Äì with Wenger shrieking at him not to go in heavy on the Gunners‚Äô star players. Parlour later told how after making a good interception, Toure followed the ball out before smashing into Wenger and leaving the man he was trying to impress in pain on the deck. Toure listened to the recording with a huge smile on his face before telling his side of the story to former Arsenal team-mate Martin Keown on talkSPORT. He said: ‚ÄúLike Martin said, I was so enthusiastic. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe I was training with these guys, coming there and with players that were my idols. When the game started, I wanted to show what I was capable of doing because for me it was a big chance and I didn‚Äôt want to miss that at all. I was trying to tackle everything I could, including the manager.‚Äù Keown added how Wenger was impressed by Toure‚Äôs mentality, immediately wanting to offer the Ivorian a contract, he said: ‚ÄúDo you remember what the manager said? He was getting to his feet and he said ‚Äòwe sign him, we sign him, please do it‚Äô.‚Äù That quip saw both of the former Invincibles burst into laughter. Toure went on to play 326 games in all competitions for Arsenal across seven years in North London ‚Äì lifting the and FA Cup twice at Arsenal. He later joined in 2009, going on to win a further Premier League title and FA Cup. After leaving the Etihad, Toure played for three years at Liverpool before moving north of the border and playing under Brendan Rodgers at Celtic for a short spell before becoming part of his coaching staff at Parkhead and . newsArray.content: C lubs with a coherent recruitment process do not really do regrets. It is why Manchester City are unlikely to be caught fretting about selling Cole Palmer to Chelsea in the summer. Outsiders may view it as a risk, particularly as Palmer is in excellent form before facing his boyhood club on Sunday afternoon, but City are hardly short of attacking talent and conduct their transfer business in a way that means they do not have to second-guess themselves about letting players go. Still Chelsea are entitled to argue that they got a bargain when they signed Palmer for ¬£40m plus ¬£2.5m in add-ons. Sometimes everyone leaves a negotiation feeling triumphant. In this case City bolstered their financial fair play position by selling a homegrown player who was on the fringes of the first team, Chelsea paid relatively little for a top young talent and Palmer joined a club who, for all their instability, were ready to offer him regular football. Nobody has to feel bitter. Palmer hoped this would be his breakthrough season at City, especially after Riyad Mahrez moved to Saudi Arabia, and there were positive signs at the start of the campaign. The 21-year-old scored a gorgeous goal against Arsenal in the Community Shield and headed in City‚Äôs equaliser against Sevilla in the European Super Cup . Was Palmer about to follow in the footsteps of another of City‚Äôs academy stars, Phil Foden, and force his way into Pep Guardiola‚Äôs plans? Foden is established with City and England, but Guardiola clearly liked Palmer and gave him opportunities last season. Cole Palmer occupies the Sevilla defence during Manchester City‚Äôs Super Cup victory in August. Photograph: Raddad Jebarah/NurPhoto/Getty Images When it came to the crunch, though, City could not quite justify keeping Palmer around. European champions tend to be ruthless. Guardiola, who also had Kevin De Bruyne, Jack Grealish, Juli√°n √Ålvarez, Bernardo Silva and Foden, looked elsewhere. The writing was on the wall for Palmer when City signed Matheus Nunes and J√©r√©my Doku. It made no sense for Palmer to stay and fight for his place. He played a key role in England winning the European Under-21 Championship in July and could not afford to be sidelined. Other avenues were waiting to be explored. City had rejected Brighton‚Äôs ¬£35m bid for Palmer and there was interest from Burnley and West Ham. Drumming up a deal for the attacker was not going to be a problem. Even so it would be wrong to say Palmer was Chelsea‚Äôs first choice given they came within a whisker of signing Michael Olise from Crystal Palace. It is true that Joe Shields, the co-director of recruitment and talent, knew Palmer from his time at City‚Äôs academy. Shields could vouch for Palmer‚Äôs ability and Chelsea spent much of the summer quietly monitoring the situation. skip past newsletter promotion Sign up to Football Daily Free daily newsletter Kick off your evenings with the Guardian's take on the world of football Privacy Notice: Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. He is a regular starter at his new club. Photograph: Javier Garc√≠a/Shutterstock Yet the move itself was opportunistic. Chelsea were short in attack after losing Christopher Nkunku and Carney Chukwuemeka to injury. Mauricio Pochettino called for reinforcements. Chelsea, notoriously blunt in the final third, needed help. However, eyebrows were raised when Palmer was added to a squad already packed with youth; it seemed odd that Chelsea would sign a right-sided attacker when they had Raheem Sterling, Noni Madueke and Mykhailo Mudryk. There were fears that Palmer would be swallowed up. He is from Wythenshawe, south Manchester, and had only known life at City. He is alone in London, away from his family, and has delivered a few self-deprecating lines about missing his mum‚Äôs cooking and learning how to use a washing machine. Do not mistake that for a lack of self-belief, though. Palmer has embraced the challenge and quickly become one of the symbols of Chelsea‚Äôs youth-led revolution. Having been eased in by Pochettino, Palmer has not looked back since coming into the starting XI. He announced himself with an assist on his debut in Brighton and excelled on his first league start, making Armando Broja‚Äôs goal in Chelsea‚Äôs win over Fulham . Pochettino has seen a player seizing responsibility. Palmer has assumed penalty duties, scoring three times from the spot, and captained England Under-21s last month. Chelsea are mid-table and have issues in attack but Palmer is not one of them. Capable of playing on the right, and even impressing as a false 9 against Arsenal last month, he has infused Pochettino‚Äôs side with ideas and invention. This is not a luxury player. When he was 16 Palmer was behind others in his age group at City. He was smaller so he focused on developing his footwork. He figured out how to escape tight situations. The growth spurt followed. At 6ft, Palmer is no pushover. He can handle the physical side, even if he still looks slender, and is not easy to dispossess. Along with the clever passing, there is an elegance to Palmer‚Äôs movement and the way he unbalances defenders. There was an instructive moment at the start of Chelsea‚Äôs wild 4-1 win over Tottenham on Monday. The visitors were under pressure after going 1-0 down and were being pressed by Spurs. But when Palmer picked up possession in his own half and found himself being pushed backwards, he stayed calm, trusted in his technique and bamboozled Destiny Udogie with a sublime Cruyff turn. No wonder Gareth Southgate is keeping an eye on Palmer, who could be drafted into the England squad after James Maddison‚Äôs withdrawal through injury. No wonder Chelsea are no longer having to answer questions about selling Mason Mount and Kai Havertz. Palmer has brightened the picture and although City will back their long-term judgment they will not underestimate their former player on Sunday afternoon.
